Identity.Basic: I'm Riccardo Mariani, an 18-year-old self-taught programmer passionate about Python and digital technologies, with over 8 years of independent learning and hands-on projects. My background combines technical problem-solving, creativity, and a drive to push beyond limits through coding.

Education.High School: I graduated from Liceo Scientifico Piero Bottoni in Milan, where I cultivated both my scientific background and programming passion. The school gave me the opportunity to combine rigorous scientific education with practical projects in computer science.
Education.University: I am currently enrolled in Computer Engineering at the Politecnico di Milano (Leonardo campus). Studying at the Politecnico is both a challenge and an honor: the university is one of the most prestigious institutions in Italy and Europe for technical education, and being part of it means belonging to a community dedicated to innovation, research, and cutting-edge engineering. My studies there are strengthening my knowledge of algorithms, electronics, and applied mathematics while giving me access to high-level research opportunities.
Education.PCTO Experience: During high school, I attended several PCTO courses at Politecnico di Milano, focusing on programming and technical skills. These experiences exposed me early to academic-level coding environments, teamwork in structured projects, and the methodologies of professional software development.

Identity.Teaching: I teach Python at my former high school, conducting extracurricular lessons for younger students. These lessons cover programming fundamentals, algorithmic thinking, and practical applications. Beyond classes, I also provide individual tutoring and project guidance, helping students design their own small-scale tools or simulations. Sharing my knowledge has become an important part of my journey, reinforcing both my technical and communication skills while building a community of motivated young programmers.

Early Exposure.Scratch: I began coding at 10 with Scratch, where I designed chat systems and RPGs using cloud variables to handle real-time interactions. Scratch allowed me to see programming as a creative tool rather than just a technical exercise, opening the door to building interactive systems from imagination alone.
Early Exposure.Transition: After Scratch, I spent a year developing an RPG in Godot with a friend. That experience introduced me to game design, scripting, and collaborative development. Soon after, I transitioned into Python and explored C and C++, giving me the ability to tackle deeper technical challenges and performance-focused coding.

Origins.Turning Point: My true passion for programming emerged during a Scratch workshop in middle school, when I realized programming could be both a universal language and a tool to model ideas and phenomena. That moment shaped my decision to pursue coding not just as a hobby but as a lifelong career path.

Overview.Volume: Over the years, I have created around 260 documented Python projects, ranging from small utilities to large-scale simulations and automation systems. This wide variety has allowed me to constantly learn, experiment, and refine both my coding style and problem-solving approach.

Categories.Automation: I developed everyday automation scripts, Minecraft mods, Telegram bots, and task schedulers. A particularly important part of my work is Telegram bot integration: I designed bots capable of remotely controlling scripts running on my PC, allowing me to manage data processing, start or stop simulations, and monitor activity in real time. These solutions made my personal workflow more efficient and also introduced me to advanced event-driven design.
Categories.Hacking: I explored ethical hacking in controlled environments, experimenting with network vulnerabilities, penetration testing, and basic backdoor prototypes. This was not about exploitation but about understanding how systems break and how they can be defended, helping me develop a strong awareness of cybersecurity principles and responsible coding practices.
Categories.Crypto: I built cryptocurrency wallet trackers and automation bots capable of monitoring balances, sending alerts, and analyzing transaction patterns. These projects integrated third-party APIs with Python workflows and gave me practical insights into the mechanics of blockchain data and financial automation.

e2D Module.Purpose: e2D is my personal Python library for 2D graphics, environments, and simulations, designed to accelerate the creation of interactive systems. It integrates graphical rendering with physical and mathematical models, making it central to most of my simulation projects.
e2D Module.Features: Its main features include vector mathematics utilities, color manipulation, input handling, collision detection, and simplified wrappers around Pygame. It also provides a specialized e2D.envs module that allows for the quick creation of environments where physical simulations and game-like interactions can be tested.
e2D Module.Maintenance: I actively maintain e2D by introducing performance upgrades and new modules. Currently, I am rewriting large portions of the library in C and C++ to drastically improve efficiency, transforming Python wrappers into compiled modules. You can see working examples of the library powering my projects such as TicTacToe AI and Electric Field Simulation.

Collabs.GitHub: I use GitHub as the central hub for my development work. There I upload projects, version-control my code, and collaborate with other developers through issues, pull requests, and contributions.
Collabs.Community: Through platforms like GitHub and my website emptyhead.dev, I actively contribute to the open-source community. I share code, exchange knowledge with other programmers, and make my libraries accessible for anyone interested in building upon them.

Projects.School Python Lessons: I led extracurricular Python lessons at Liceo Scientifico Piero Bottoni. The lessons started with basic input/output and syntax, but gradually expanded to cover data structures, algorithm design, and problem-solving strategies. I encouraged students to complete small projects, such as calculators, games, and text-based systems, to strengthen their understanding. These lessons not only gave students practical skills but also allowed me to refine my own teaching style and leadership abilities.

High Performance.Particle Engines: I created particle simulators capable of managing tens of thousands of particles in real time, ensuring stable frame rates through optimized algorithms and GPU-friendly designs.
High Performance.Optimization: My focus has been on pushing Python beyond its usual limits, using NumPy for vectorization, Numba for JIT compilation, and Cython/C++ modules for the most computationally expensive sections.

Physics Models.Mechanics: My simulations cover Newtonian mechanics, collision dynamics, multi-body problems, gravitational interactions, and constraint-based systems such as springs or rigid rods. These allow me to test both theoretical physics and creative experimental setups.
Physics Models.Numerical Methods: I frequently apply iterative numerical methods, differential solvers, and custom vectorized algorithms to achieve realistic system behavior. By carefully profiling performance, I optimize step sizes and solver strategies to balance accuracy and efficiency.

Algorithms.Reinforcement: I designed Q-learning agents capable of learning policies in custom environments, from simple games to optimization problems. These experiments helped me understand the balance between exploration and exploitation.
Algorithms.Neural Networks: I experimented with PyTorch and TensorFlow, training deep learning models and also coding basic neural networks from scratch. This gave me a deep understanding of the mechanics of backpropagation and gradient descent.
Algorithms.NEAT: I applied NeuroEvolution of Augmenting Topologies (NEAT) to evolve agents in simulations, particularly in environments where adaptability and emergent behavior were essential.

Application Areas.Simulation Projects: My AI experiments span a wide range of domains: self-driving car simulations in simplified road environments, inverted pendulum control to test feedback loops, and evolutionary ecosystems. For example, I developed ant colony systems with pheromone trails and predator-prey models with foxes, rabbits, and carrots. These projects show how computation and natural behaviors can intersect to produce unexpected and emergent results.

Programming Stack.Languages: I mainly use Python, C, C++, JavaScript, and GDScript (Godot). C and C++ are not only languages I explored academically but also essential tools I use for optimization and low-level integration with Python projects.
Programming Stack.Python Libraries: My daily stack includes NumPy, Numba, Cython, TensorFlow, PyTorch, and especially my custom e2D library. This library acts as a multipurpose tool that streamlines 2D simulation and game design.

DevOps.Versioning: I work with Git and GitHub to track every stage of development, ensuring structured project histories, reproducible results, and easier collaboration.
DevOps.Deployment: I manage my personal domain emptyhead.dev, handling advanced hosting practices. This includes maintaining live servers, transferring files, publishing interactive simulations, and presenting my portfolio online.

Workflow.IDE\\Editors: My workflow revolves around VSCode, where I developed extensive shortcut knowledge for maximum productivity. For game and simulation projects, I rely on Godotâ€™s editor, which integrates scripting and scene design in one platform.
Workflow.Testing: I combine manual testing with debugging, logging, and occasional unit tests for critical functions. For performance-sensitive work, I depend heavily on profiling tools to identify and fix bottlenecks.
Workflow.Publishing: Currently, I am focusing on publishing my most relevant projects on my website in a dedicated portfolio section. The goal is to create a well-documented showcase accessible to the public, highlighting polished and interactive work.
